video.title_en: Who Invented Telephone? | Invention of Telephone

summary.text_en: On March 7, 1876, Alexander Graham Bell was granted US Patent 174,465, often considered the most valuable patent in history. It described his 'Telephone', a device capable of converting the 'vibrations of the human voice' (sound waves) into an 'electrical signal', transmitting it over a wire, and converting it back into 'sound' at the other end. Three days later, on March 10, he transmitted the first clear sentence: 'Mr. Watsonâ€”Come hereâ€”I want to see you!'
key_points_en: Granted one of the most valuable patents in history (US 174,465)
First device to transmit human *speech* electrically

story.text_en: Bell's invention was the result of a fierce 'patent race'. Another inventor, Elisha Gray, filed a 'patent caveat' for a similar telephone design on the *exact same day* (Feb 14, 1876). Bell's application was filed just hours earlier, securing him the patent. Bell's first working transmitter (the 'liquid transmitter') worked by having a 'diaphragm' vibrate a needle in 'acidified water' (a conductive liquid). This vibration changed the 'resistance' of the circuit, creating an 'undulating current' that *mirrored the waveform* of the human voice. This principle of 'copying the sound wave' was the secret.

fun_facts.text_en: The first famous sentence ('Mr. Watsonâ€”Come here!') was an accident. Bell had just spilled 'sulfuric acid' (from the liquid transmitter) on his pants and was crying out for help.
Both Bell's mother and his wife were deaf. His lifelong obsession with 'sound' and 'speech' stemmed from his desire to help the deaf communicate.

simple_explanation.text_en:
Before Bell, the telegraph (`morse_code_1837`) could only send 'beeps' (Morse code).
Bell's great invention was teaching *electricity* how to *sing*.
He built a 'mechanical ear' (a diaphragm) that 'listened' to the *vibrations* of your voice. It then *copied* those exact vibrations into an *electrical current*. At the other end, a 'mechanical mouth' (the receiver) turned that 'vibrating current' back into *sound*.
He turned a 'sound wave' into an 'electric wave' and back again.

applications.text_en: The telephone 'receiver' (turning electricity into sound) is the direct ancestor of all modern 'loudspeakers' and 'headphones'.

impact.text_en: The telephone was the most important invention of the latter 19th century. It completed the 'annihilation of distance' that the telegraph began. It translated the physics of Faraday (`faraday_induction_1831`) and Helmholtz (`helmholtz_acoustics_1863`) into an everyday technology that connected humanity. It launched the 'telecoms age' and built the network infrastructure that the 20th-century radio (`marconi_radio_1895`) and 21st-century internet would be built upon.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Helmholtz (his 'Sensations of Tone' and work on 'acoustics' was the theoretical basis for Bell's understanding of speech vibrations)
Faraday (his 'electromagnetic induction' was the principle behind Bell's (and Gray's) magnetic telephone design)
Morse's Telegraph (Bell's initial goal was to 'improve' the telegraph, to send multiple messages at once)
Antonio Meucci (his 1857 'Telettrofono' was the primary (early) challenger to Bell's patent)
Johann Philipp Reis (his 'Telephon's' *failure* to transmit speech was used by Bell to prove his 'undulating current' was novel)
Elisha Gray (his 'patent caveat' and 'liquid transmitter' design, filed the *same day*, was Bell's greatest legal and technical rival)

influenced.contribution_en: Thomas Edison (his 'phonograph' and 'carbon microphone' were directly inspired by trying to improve Bell's telephone)
Marconi (his 'radio' was initially conceived as 'wireless telephony', an extension of Bell's idea)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Alexander Graham Bell taught 'electricity' how to 'talk'.

quiz.question_en: What fundamental breakthrough did Alexander Graham Bell's 1876 'Telephone' achieve over the 'Telegraph'?
options_en: It could transmit the *human voice*, not just 'beeps' (Morse code)
quiz.explanation_en: The telegraph (`morse_code_1837`) could only send 'on' or 'off' signals (dots and dashes). Bell's telephone was the first device to replicate the complex *waveform* of a *sound wave* into an *electrical current*, thus transmitting *speech*.
